edamame.eda module

edamame.eda.correlation_categorical(data) → None[source]

The function performs the Chi-Square Test of Independence between categorical variables of the dataset.

data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame

None

edamame.eda.correlation_pearson(data, threshold: float = 0.0) → None[source]

The function performs the Pearson’s correlation between the columns pairs.

data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame threshold: float

Only the correlation values higher than the threshold are shown in the matrix. A floating value set by default to 0.

None

edamame.eda.correlation_phik(data, theory: bool = False) → None[source]

Paper link: https://arxiv.org/pdf/1811.11440.pdf

data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame theory: bool

A boolean value for displaying insight into the theory of the Phik correlation index. By default is set to False.

None

edamame.eda.drop_columns(data, col: list[str])[source]

The function returns a pandas dataframe with the columns selected dropped.

data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame col: list[str]

A list of strings containing the names of columns to drop.

pandas.core.frame.DataFrame

edamame.eda.handling_missing(data, col: list[str], missing_val=nan, method: list[str] = [])[source]

The function returns a pandas dataframe with the columns selected modified to handle the nan values.

data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame col: list[str]

A list of the names of the dataframe columns to handle.

missing_val:

The value that represents the NA in the columns passed. By default is equal to np.nan.

method:

A list of the names of the methods (mean, median, most_frequent, drop) applied to the columns passed. By default, if nothing was indicated, the function applied the most_frequent method to all the columns passed. Indicating fewer methods than the names of the columns leads to an autocompletion with the most_frequent method.

pandas.core.frame.DataFrame

edamame.eda.identify_types(data) → list[list[str]][source]

The function display the result of the dtypes method

data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame

list

A list with the name of the numerical columns and a list with the name of the columns identified as “object” by pandas.

edamame.eda.inspection(data, threshold: int = 10, bins: int = 50, figsize: tuple[float, float] = (6.0, 4.0)) → None[source]

The function displays an interactive plot for analysing the distribution of a variable based on the distinct cardinalities of the target variable.

data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame threshold: int

A value for determining the maximum number of distinct cardinalities the target variable can have. By default is set to 10.

bins: int

The number of bins used by the histograms. By default bins=50.

figsize: tuple[float, float]

A tuple to determine the plot size.

None

edamame.eda.interaction(data) → None[source]

The function display an interactive plot for analysing relationships between numerical columns with a scatterplot.

data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame

None

edamame.eda.missing(data) → list[list[str]][source]

The function display the following elements: - A table with the percentage of NA record for every column. - A table with the percentage of 0 as a record for every column. - A table with the percentage of duplicate rows. - A list of lists that contains the name of the numerical columns with NA, the name of the categorical columns with NA and the name of the columns with 0 as a record.

data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame

list

A list that contains the name of the numerical columns with NA, the name of the categorical columns with NA and the name of the columns with 0 as a record.

edamame.eda.modify_cardinality(data, col: list[str], threshold: list[int])[source]

The function returns a pandas dataframe with the cardinalities of the columns selected modified.

data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame col: list[str]

A list of strings containing the names of columns for which we want to modify the cardinalities.

threshold: list[int]

A list of integer values containing the threshold values for every variable.

pandas.core.frame.DataFrame

edamame.eda.num_variable_study(data, col: str, bins: int = 50, epsilon: float = 0.0001, theory: bool = False) → None[source]

The function displays the following transformations of the variable col passed: log(x), sqrt(x), x^2, Box-cox, 1/x

data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame col: str

The name of the dataframe column to study.

bins: int

The number of bins used by the histograms. By default bins=50.

epsilon: float

A constant for handle non strictly positive variables. By default epsilon = 0.0001

theory: bool

A boolean value for displaying insight into the transformations applied

None

edamame.eda.split_and_scaling(data, target: str, minmaxscaler: bool = False)[source]
The function returns two pandas dataframes:

  • The regressor matrix X contains all the predictors for the model.

  • The series y contains the values of the response variable.

In addition, the function applies a step of standard scaling on the numerical columns of the X matrix.

data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame target: str

The response variable column name.

minmaxscaler: bool

Select the type of scaling to apply to the numerical columns.

pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, pandas.core.frame.DataFrame

edamame.eda.view_cardinality(data, col: list[str]) → None[source]

The function especially helps study the cardinalities of the categorical variables.

data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame col: list[str]

A list of strings containing the names of columns for which we want to show the number of unique values.

None

edamame.tools.scaling(X, minmaxscaler: bool = False)[source]

The function returns the normalised matrix.

X: pandas.DataFrame

The model matrix X/X_train/X_test

minmaxscaler: bool

Select the type of scaling to apply to the numerical columns.

pandas.DataFrame

edamame.tools.setup(X, y, dummy: bool = False, seed: int = 42, size: float = 0.25)[source]

The function returns the following elements: X_train, y_train, X_test, y_test.

X: pandas.DataFrame

The model matrix X (features matrix)

y: pandas.DataFrame

The target variable

dummy: bool

If False, the function produces the OHE. If True, the dummy encoding

seed: int

Random seed to apply at the train_test_split function

size: float

Size of the test dataset

pandas.DataFrame, pandas.DataFrame, pandas.DataFrame, pandas.DataFrame
